lines.text:
[Books has just given Gillom a shooting lesson]
But how could you get into so many fights and always come out on top? I nearly tied you shooting.

Friend, there's nobody up there shooting back at you. It isn't always being fast or even accurate that counts. It's being willing. I found out early that most men, regardless of cause or need, aren't willing. They blink an eye or draw a breath before they pull the trigger. I won't.
The day they lay you away, what I'll do on your grave won't pass for flowers.
Damn.
John Bernard, you swear too much.
The hell I do.

There - there's one more thing I'd say. Both of us have had a lot to do with death. I'm not a brave man, but you must be. Now, now, now, this is not advice. It's not even a suggestion. It's just something for you to reflect on while your mind's still clear.
What?
I would not die a death like I just described.
No?
Not if I had your courage.
Mike Sweeney?
John Bernard Books, now I'm flattered that you remembered me.
Well, you look just how I remembered the Sweeneys - mean and ugly.
[Books has just had a conversation with Mike Sweeney]
How do you know him?
I don't. I had some dealings with his brother Albert once.
What happened?
[Books looks at her]
Oh.
Now, I checked my bulletins before I come over and didn't find nothing I can hold you for, but I want you out of town - directly, today.
Maybe I'm not so inclined.
The, by God, I will incline you. I can badge as many men as I need. We'll smoke you out or carry you out feet first, so you say which, Mr. Gunman. It's your funeral.
Soon, yes.
Huh?
I can't go.
Can't?
I'm going to die right here in this room.
Heh! That's too thin.
I wish you were right. Would you believe Doc Hostetler? That's his verdict.

You don't say? You don't sa - goddamn! Whoo! Whooee! I tell you the damn truth, when I come through that door, I was scared. 'Cause I know what a man like you is capable of. I wondered who'd get my job, if the council would give my wife a pension and if it would snow the day they put me under. Whooee! Excuse me if I don't pull a long face. I can't.
Pulford, J.B. Books over at Mrs. Rogers'...
Yeah, but I just heard he's dyin'.
Dyin'?
A friend a' mine got it from Marshal Thibido himself. Ol' Books is cashin' in.
That's hard news. That's a man I coulda taken.

[laughs]
My ass.
You have two ways of leaving this establishment, my friend. Immediately or dead.
To put it in a nutshell, you've plum wore us out.
Put it in a nutshell? You couldn't put it in a barrel without a bottom. You're the longest winded bastard I've ever known.

[to the bumbling bandit who attempts to rob him in the first scene]
Friend, you better get another line of work; this one sure don't fit your pistol.

[putting his gun to Dobkins's mouth]
Make like that's a nipple.
Mr. Books, you're the most famous man I ever knew, and the second bes' haggler.
Who's the best?

[smiling broadly]
Here I stand.
Books, every few days I have to tell a man or a woman something I don't want to. I've been practicing medicine for 29 years, and I still don't know how to do it well.
Why don't you just say it flat out?
All right. You have a cancer - advanced. Is that what that fella up in Creed told you?
Yeah.
And you didn't believe him.
No.
Do you believe me?
Can't you cut it out, Doc?
I'd have to gut you like a fish.
Well, what *can* you do?
There's... just, uh... very little I can do. Uh, if... when the pain gets too bad, I can give you something.
What you're trying to tell me is that I...
Yeah.
Damn.
Did you read about the shooting the night before last at the Metropole?
No.

Whoee! That was some shooting. Pulford, he's the faro dealer, got off one round under fire. Straight through the heart., and it measured 84 feet 3 inches. Maybe I'll just send him here, let him deal you a little faro.
How are you feeling? A little more poorly everyday?
You have a streak of kindness a mile wide.
That I do.
I'm a dying man, scared of the dark.
Damn you! Damn you for the pain you brought into this house.
Bat Masterson told Cobb...

[Interrupts]
Bat Masterson?
Yeah, he said that a man has to have guts, deliberation and a proficiency with fire arms.
Did he mention that third eye you better have?
Third eye?

For that dumbass amateur. There's always some six-fingered bustard that couldn't hit a cow in the tit with a tin cup. That's the one who usually does you in. But Masterson always was full of... sheep-dip.

[after shooting Books]
I'll tell you, that was for Albert!

[after Gillom tells him that Pulford and Cobb will be at the Metropole the next day]
What about the other one, Mike Sweeney?
Now you watch out for him, Mr. Books. He's mean, and he hates you.
Well, we'll see if we can't clear that up tomorrow.
You wouldn't gun down a police officer.
What'd stop me? Fear of dying?
Bond, I don't believe I ever killed a man that didn't deserve it.
Surely only the Lord can judge that.

[pointing to Books' pillow]
Well if I wanted to go around town unnoticed, I wouldn't carry *that* around with me.

[smiling]
Stole it from a whore house in Creed.

[haggling over the price of Books' horse]
$295... $296... $297... $298...
Whoa.
Two ninety - you mean I can - why Mr. Books, that makes me the bes' haggler!
Best in the world, Moses.
[Moses laughs]
First things, first, Doc. I almost forgot to ask you. How much do I owe you?
You're a man after my own heart, Books. Most of them ask that last, if at all. Well, let's see. We'll make it four dollars for the two visits plus one dollar for that.
What's that.?
They call that laudanum, a solution of opium and alcohol.

[Clearly depressed when Hostetler tells him his cancer is fatal]
You told me I was strong as an ox!
Well, even an ox dies.

[addressing the barman after entering the bar where his last gunfight will take place]
Mister, this is my birthday. Gimme the best in the house.

[Gillom is dusting off a carriage as Books and Mrs. Rogers prepare for a drive to Lake Tahoe]
Moses says he don't rent out this buggy too often.
Doesn't.
'Doesn't'... except for funerals.
Where's Gillom?
In the woodshed.
That's appropriate.
Why?
You stay outta this.
Where are you from, Mr. Hickock?
Abilene, Texas
And what do you do there?
United States Marshall
That's nice.
No it isn't.

[to Gillam]
Would you tell Mrs. Rogers that a tuckered out old man would like a room?
[last lines]
LOOK OUT!
I won't be wronged, I won't be insulted, and I won't be laid a hand on. I don't do these things to other people, and I require the same from them.
